query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Lo giorno se n’andava, e l’aere bruno 2 toglieva li animai che sono in terra 3 da le fatiche loro; e io sol uno
4 m’apparecchiava a sostener la guerra 5 sì del cammino e sì de la pietate, 6 che ritrarrà la mente che non erra.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The day was departing, and the dusky air 2 was taking away from animals on earth 3 their labors; and I alone
4 was preparing myself to endure the struggle 5 of the journey and of pity, 6 which the mind that does not err will recall.
**Old English:**
1 Se dæg wæs agangen, and ðæt brune lyft 2 benam ða gesceaft þe on foldan sind 3 heora geswinces; and ic sylfa ana
4 me gegearwode ðæt ic ða gewinn þolode 5 ge ðæs weges ge ðære wædle, 6 ðe se ðonc ðe ne dreogeð eft gemæneð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 O muse, o alto ingegno, or m’aiutate; 8 o mente che scrivesti ciò ch’io vidi, 9 qui si parrà la tua nobilitate.
query.result:
**English:**
7 O Muses, O lofty genius, now help me; 8 O memory that wrote down what I saw, 9 here your nobility will be revealed.
**Old English:**
7 Eala, musa, eala, heahgemynd, nu me gehelpað; 8 eala, ðu mod ðe ðæt gesawe, nu hit awrite, 9 her bið gesyne ðin æðelborennes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Io cominciai: «Poeta che mi guidi, 11 guarda la mia virtù s’ell’ è possente, 12 prima ch’a l’alto passo tu mi fidi.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I began: "Poet who guide me, 11 consider my strength to see if it is sufficient, 12 before you trust me with the difficult journey."
**Old English:**
10 Ic ongan ða: "Þu þe me lædest, leofra frēond, 11 geseoh ðu hwæðer min mægen sy to ðære færan, 12 ær ðu me læde ofer ðone hean hrof."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Tu dici che di Silvïo il parente, 14 corruttibile ancora, ad immortale 15 secolo andò, e fu sensibilmente.
query.result:
**English:**
13 You say that the son of Silvius, 14 still corruptible, went to the immortal 15 century, and was there in the flesh.
**Old English:**
13 ðu segst ðæt ðæs Silviuses sunu, 14 ðeah ðe he wære brosniende, to ðæm unbrosniendlican 15 worulde gewende and ðær wæs on gesewenlicum lichoman.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Però, se l’avversario d’ogne male 17 cortese i fu, pensando l’alto effetto 18 ch’uscir dovea di lui, e ’l chi e ’l quale
19 non pare indegno ad omo d’intelletto; 20 ch’e’ fu de l’alma Roma e di suo impero 21 ne l’empireo ciel per padre eletto:
22 la quale e ’l quale, a voler dir lo vero, 23 fu stabilita per lo loco santo 24 u’ siede il successor del maggior Piero.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Therefore, if the adversary of all evil 17 was courteous to him, considering the high effect 18 that was to come from him, and who and what he was,
19 it does not seem unworthy to a man of intellect; 20 for he was of noble Rome and of her empire 21 chosen in the empyrean heaven as father:
22 who and what, to tell the truth, 23 was established by the holy place 24 where sits the successor of the greatest Peter.
**Old English:**
16 Forðæm, gif se widerwearda ealra yfla 17 wæs him arfæst, ðendende he hogode ðone hean effect 18 ðe sceolde cuman of him, and ðone hwa and ðone hwæt,
19 nis ðæt unweorð mannum to gehyranne; 20 forðæm he wæs of ðære æðelan Rome and of hire rice 21 on ðam heofonlican heofone to fæder gecoren:
22 ða hwa and ða hwæt, to secganne ða soðan, 23 wæs gestaðelod ðurh ða halgan stowe 24 ðær sited se æftergenga ðæs mæstan Petres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Per quest’ andata onde li dai tu vanto, 26 intese cose che furon cagione 27 di sua vittoria e del papale ammanto.
query.result:
**English:**
25 For this journey, for which you give him praise, 26 he heard things that were the cause 27 of his victory and of the papal mantle.
**Old English:**
25 For ðære fare ðe ðu him fremest, 26 he ða ðing gehyrde ðe wæron ðære 27 his sige and ðæs papan pallium.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Andovvi poi lo Vas d’elezïone, 29 per recarne conforto a quella fede 30 ch’è principio a la via di salvazione.
query.result:
**English:**
28 And then went the Vessel of Election, 29 to bring comfort to that faith 30 which is the beginning of the way of salvation.
**Old English:**
28 And ða gewende se Ceosena Fugel, 29 ðæt he ðære geleafan frofre gefremede, 30 ðe is anginn ðæs weg to hæle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Ma io, perché venirvi? o chi ’l concede? 32 Io non Enëa, io non Paulo sono; 33 me degno a ciò né io né altri ’l crede.
query.result:
**English:**
31 But I, why should I come there? Or who permits it? 32 I am not Aeneas, I am not Paul; 33 neither I nor anyone else believes me worthy of this.
**Old English:**
31 Ac ic, for hwi sceal ic ðær cuman? oððe hwa ðæt lyfð? 32 Ne eom ic Æneas, ne ic Paulus; 33 ne ic ne oðer mon ne weneð ðæt ic ðæs wyrðe sy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Per che, se del venire io m’abbandono, 35 temo che la venuta non sia folle. 36 Se’ savio; intendi me’ ch’i’ non ragiono».
query.result:
**English:**
34 Therefore, if I abandon myself to going, 35 I fear that the coming may not be wise. 36 You are wise; understand me, for I do not speak clearly.
**Old English:**
34 Forðæm, gif ic ðæs cumes me sylf begyfe, 35 ic ondræde ðæt ðæt cuma ne sie dysig. 36 ðu eart wis; ðu ongýtst me ðeah ðe ic ne secge.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 E qual è quei che disvuol ciò che volle 38 e per novi pensier cangia proposta, 39 sì che dal cominciar tutto si tolle,
40 tal mi fec’ ïo ’n quella oscura costa, 41 perché, pensando, consumai la ’mpresa 42 che fu nel cominciar cotanto tosta.
query.result:
**English:**
37 And just as he who changes his mind about what he wanted 38 and, because of new thoughts, changes his plan, 39 so that he completely abandons what he started,
40 so I did on that dark hillside, 41 because, by thinking, I gave up the enterprise 42 that was so bold when I began it.
**Old English:**
37 And swa swa se ðe his willan awent, 38 and ðurh niwe ðohtas his ðanc awent, 39 ðæt he ðæt ðing forlæt ðe he ær ongon,
40 ðus ic wearð on ðære dimman sæcce, 41 ðurh ðæt ic ða ðohtas ða dæd forlæt 42 ðe ic ær ongon swa deorclice.

**English:**
43 "If I have understood your words well," 44 replied that shade of the magnanimous one, 45 "your soul is offended by cowardice,
46 which often encumbers a man 47 so that it turns him away from an honorable enterprise, 48 like a false vision of a beast when it is a shadow.
**Old English:**
43 "Gif ic ða word ðine wel gehyrde," 44 andswarode ðæs ofermōdes ðæt gesceaft, 45 "ðin mōd is mid manfullnesse oferbræded;
46 ðæt ðe oft gelōme ðone līg mengan 47 ðæt ðe ðonne from æðelum weorce awent, 48 swā swā unriht gesihð ðone wildeor ðonne hit sceadu bið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Da questa tema acciò che tu ti solve, 50 dirotti perch’ io venni e quel ch’io ’ntesi 51 nel primo punto che di te mi dolve.
query.result:
**English:**
49 So that you may free yourself from this fear, 50 I will tell you why I came and what I heard 51 at the first moment that I felt pity for you.
**Old English:**
49 Þæt ðu ðe ðisne ege forbuge, 50 ic ðe secge hwi ic com and hwæt ic ðær gehyrde 51 æt ðam forman siðe ðe ic ðinre hreowsode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Io era tra color che son sospesi, 53 e donna mi chiamò beata e bella, 54 tal che di comandare io la richiesi.
query.result:
**English:**
52 I was among those who are suspended, 53 and a lady called me blessed and beautiful, 54 so that I asked her to command me.
**Old English:**
52 Ic wæs on ðæm ðe syndon ahafen, 53 and ða clypode me sum wif fæger and gesælig, 54 swa ðæt ic ða bæd ðæt heo me rædan sceolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Lucevan li occhi suoi più che la stella; 56 e cominciommi a dir soave e piana, 57 con angelica voce, in sua favella:
58 “O anima cortese mantoana, 59 di cui la fama ancor nel mondo dura, 60 e durerà quanto ’l mondo lontana,
61 l’amico mio, e non de la ventura, 62 ne la diserta piaggia è impedito 63 sì nel cammin, che vòlt’ è per paura;
64 e temo che non sia già sì smarrito, 65 ch’io mi sia tardi al soccorso levata, 66 per quel ch’i’ ho di lui nel cielo udito.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Her eyes shone brighter than the stars; 56 and she began to speak to me softly and gently, 57 with an angelic voice, in her own language:
58 "O courteous Mantuan soul, 59 whose fame still endures in the world, 60 and will endure as long as the world lasts,
61 my friend, and not of fortune, 62 is hindered on the deserted shore, 63 so much on his journey that he has turned back in fear;
64 and I fear that he may already be so lost, 65 that I may have risen too late to his aid, 66 from what I have heard of him in heaven.
**Old English:**
55 Leohte wæron hire eagan ma ðonne steorra; 56 and heo ongan ða to sprecenne mildelice and stillum, 57 mid engliscre stefne, on hire agenre spræce:
58 "Ea, ðu arfæste Mantinisce sawl, 59 ðære lof wide geond ðas world wunað, 60 and wunað swa lange swa ðeos world standeð,
61 min freond, and na ðære gesælda, 62 on ðære weste strande is gehinderod 63 swa on ðam wege, ðæt he is ondrædendlic geworden;
64 and ic ondræde ðæt he ne beo nu swa gedwolod, 65 ðæt ic beo to læt to ðam fultum aræred, 66 ðurh ðæt ðe ic be him on heofonum gehyrde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Or movi, e con la tua parola ornata 68 e con ciò c’ha mestieri al suo campare, 69 l’aiuta sì ch’i’ ne sia consolata.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Now move, and with your ornate speech 68 and with what is necessary for his sustenance, 69 help him so that I may be consoled by it.
**Old English:**
67 Nu ðu most faran and ðinre fægran spræce 68 and ðæs ðe his neod is to libbanne, 69 gefultumian ðæt ic ðæs gefrefrod sie.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Quando sarò dinanzi al segnor mio, 74 di te mi loderò sovente a lui”. 75 Tacette allora, e poi comincia’ io:
76 “O donna di virtù sola per cui 77 l’umana spezie eccede ogne contento 78 di quel ciel c’ha minor li cerchi sui,
79 tanto m’aggrada il tuo comandamento, 80 che l’ubidir, se già fosse, m’è tardi; 81 più non t’è uo’ ch’aprirmi il tuo talento.
query.result:
**English:**
73 When I shall be before my Lord, 74 I shall often praise you to him.” 75 Then she was silent, and then I began:
76 “O lady of virtue, alone through whom 77 the human race surpasses every joy 78 of that heaven which has its orbits smallest,
79 your command pleases me so much 80 that to obey it, if it were already possible, would be late for me; 81 I desire nothing more from you than to reveal your wish to me.
**Old English:**
73 Þonne ic beo beforan minum Drihtne, 74 ic ðe gelomelice lofige to him.” 75 Þa geswog heo ða, and ða ic ongan:
76 “Eala ðu mægð mægena strengest, ðurh ðe an 77 moncyn ofer ealle ða gesceafta 78 ðæs heofonrices hafað ða lytlan hringas,
79 swa me ðin boda byð swiðe leof, 80 ðæt ðin bebod, gif hit ðu syllan woldest, 81 ne mæg ic ðe ðæs ðances geðancian.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Ma dimmi la cagion che non ti guardi 83 de lo scender qua giuso in questo centro 84 de l’ampio loco ove tornar tu ardi”.
query.result:
**English:**
82 But tell me the reason why you do not protect yourself 83 from descending down here into this center 84 of the vast place to which you burn to return”.
**Old English:**
82 Ac sege me ðone intingan hwi du ðe ne bewerest 83 ðæt ðu ne astige her niðer on ðisne grund 84 ðæs miclan stowe ðe ðu wilnast to cymenne”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 “Da che tu vuo’ saver cotanto a dentro, 86 dirotti brievemente”, mi rispuose, 87 “perch’ i’ non temo di venir qua entro.
query.result:
**English:**
85 “Since you want to know so deeply, 86 I will tell you briefly,” he replied to me, 87 “because I do not fear coming in here.
**Old English:**
85 “Nu ðu wilt witan swa deoplice, 86 ic ðe sceal secgan sceortlice,” he me andswarode, 87 “forðæm ic ne ondræde ðe her in to cumenne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Temer si dee di sole quelle cose 89 c’hanno potenza di fare altrui male; 90 de l’altre no, ché non son paurose.
query.result:
**English:**
88 One should only fear those things 89 that have the power to harm others; 90 not the others, for they are not fearsome.
**Old English:**
88 Ege sceal mon habban ana ða anan ðing 89 ðe ðæt geweald habbað ðæt hi oðrum men misdón magon; 90 ðara oðra ðinga ne sceal mon, forðæm ðe hi ne sind na egeslice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 I’ son fatta da Dio, sua mercé, tale, 92 che la vostra miseria non mi tange, 93 né fiamma d’esto ’ncendio non m’assale.
query.result:
**English:**
91 I have been made by God, through his mercy, such 92 that your misery does not touch me, 93 nor does the flame of this fire assail me.
**Old English:**
91 Ic eom geworden fram Gode, ðurh his mildse, swylc, 92 ðæt ðin earmðu ne hrepð me nænigu, 93 ne ðæs lig egesan ðisne ne geswencð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Donna è gentil nel ciel che si compiange 95 di questo ’mpedimento ov’ io ti mando, 96 sì che duro giudicio là sù frange.
query.result:
**English:**
94 A gentle lady in Heaven grieves 95 over this hindrance to which I send you, 96 so that harsh judgment up there is broken.
**Old English:**
94 Wif is on heofonum ðe ðisne hreoh 95 ðurh ðisne gesceaft bemeornað, 96 ðæt ðær ðone heardan dom forðbreceð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Questa chiese Lucia in suo dimando 98 e disse:—Or ha bisogno il tuo fedele 99 di te, e io a te lo raccomando—.
query.result:
**English:**
97 This Lucia asked in her request 98 and said: "Now your faithful one has need 99 of you, and I commend him to you."
**Old English:**
97 Þis Lucię bæd on hire bene 98 and cwæð: "Nu ðin leofa ðearfe hæfð 99 ðinre, and ic hine ðe bebeode."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Lucia, nimica di ciascun crudele, 101 si mosse, e venne al loco dov’ i’ era, 102 che mi sedea con l’antica Rachele.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Lucia, enemy of every cruelty, 101 moved, and came to the place where I was, 102 where I sat with the ancient Rachel.
**Old English:**
100 Lucia, feond ðæs cræftan cræftes, 101 heo hire ongon ða stigan, and ðær heo ða gestod, 102 ðær ic sæt mid ðære ealdan Rachele.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Disse:—Beatrice, loda di Dio vera, 104 ché non soccorri quei che t’amò tanto, 105 ch’uscì per te de la volgare schiera?
106 Non odi tu la pieta del suo pianto, 107 non vedi tu la morte che ’l combatte 108 su la fiumana ove ’l mar non ha vanto?—.
query.result:
**English:**
103 She said: "Beatrice, true praise of God, 104 why do you not help the one who loved you so much, 105 that he left the common crowd for you?
106 Do you not hear the pity of his weeping, 107 do you not see the death that fights him 108 on the river where the sea has no power?"
**Old English:**
103 Cwæð:—Beatrice, lóf Godes sóðe, 104 hví ne gehelpeð ðú ðæm ðe ðe lufode swíðe, 105 ðe for ðe út eode of ðære folcsceare?
106 Ne gehyrst ðú ðæs weopes hryre, 107 ne gesyhst ðú ðone deað ðe hine winneð 108 ofer ðære ea ðær se sæ næfð geweald?—.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Al mondo non fur mai persone ratte 110 a far lor pro o a fuggir lor danno, 111 com’ io, dopo cotai parole fatte,
112 venni qua giù del mio beato scanno, 113 fidandomi del tuo parlare onesto, 114 ch’onora te e quei ch’udito l’hanno”.
query.result:
**English:**
109 In the world there never were people so quick 110 to do their good or to flee from their harm, 111 as I, after such words were spoken,
112 came down here from my blessed seat, 113 trusting in your honest speech, 114 which honors you and those who have heard it.
**Old English:**
109 On worulde næfre wæron men swa hræde 110 to donne heora frofre oððe fleonne heora hryre, 111 swa ic, æfter ðam wordum ðe ðu geworht hæfst,
112 com her niðer of minum beorhtan stole, 113 truwiende ðinum wordum ðe ðu geworht hæfst, 114 ðe nu wurðiað ðe and ða ðe ða gehyrdon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Poscia che m’ebbe ragionato questo, 116 li occhi lucenti lagrimando volse, 117 per che mi fece del venir più presto.
query.result:
**English:**
115 After he had spoken thus to me, 116 he turned his shining eyes, weeping, 117 so that he made me come more quickly.
**Old English:**
115 Þa he ðis to me sæde, 116 his eagum leohte wepende gewende, 117 swa ðæt he me to ðam siðe selran macode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 E venni a te così com’ ella volse: 119 d’inanzi a quella fiera ti levai 120 che del bel monte il corto andar ti tolse.
query.result:
**English:**
118 And I came to you just as she wished: 119 you rose up before that beast 120 that kept you from the short journey up the fair mountain.
**Old English:**
118 And ic com to ðe swa swa heo wolde: 119 ðu ðe aræerest ðære fyrenan, 120 ðe ðe ðæs fægran muntes sceortne sið beneom.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Dunque: che è? perché, perché restai, 122 perché tanta viltà nel core allette, 123 perché ardire e franchezza non hai,
124 poscia che tai tre donne benedette 125 curan di te ne la corte del cielo, 126 e ’l mio parlar tanto ben ti promette?».
query.result:
**English:**
121 So then: what is it? Why, why did you remain, 122 why do you foster such cowardice in your heart, 123 why do you have no boldness and courage,
124 since three such blessed ladies 125 care for you in the court of heaven, 126 and my words promise you such good things?”.
**Old English:**
121 Þonne: hwæt is ðæt? Hwi, hwi ðu ðær wune, 122 hwi ðu on ðinum breostum ðone unræd lætst, 123 hwi ðu ðone ellen and ðone ofermægen næfst,
124 siððan ðe ða ðreo gesæligan ðegnunge 125 on heofona rice reccað, 126 and ðin spræc ðe swylcne from hafað?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Quali fioretti dal notturno gelo 128 chinati e chiusi, poi che ’l sol li ’mbianca, 129 si drizzan tutti aperti in loro stelo,
130 tal mi fec’ io di mia virtude stanca, 131 e tanto buono ardire al cor mi corse, 132 ch’i’ cominciai come persona franca:
133 «Oh pietosa colei che mi soccorse! 134 e te cortese ch’ubidisti tosto 135 a le vere parole che ti porse!
136 Tu m’hai con disiderio il cor disposto 137 sì al venir con le parole tue, 138 ch’i’ son tornato nel primo proposto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Like little flowers which, bowed down and closed 128 by the chill of night, after the sun whitens them, 129 all open on their stems,
130 so I made myself of my weary virtue, 131 and so much good boldness ran to my heart 132 that I began like a person who is free:
133 “O compassionate one who helped me! 134 And you, courteous one, who promptly obeyed 135 the true words that she spoke to you!
136 You have disposed my heart with desire 137 to come with your words, 138 so that I have returned to my first intention.
**Old English:**
127 Swa ða blostman be nihtes cele 128 bið gehnægð and belocen, ðonne sunne hine bled, 129 ahebbað hi ða heafdu on heora stelum,
130 swa ic ða dyde of minre wædle mode, 131 and swa micel gleawnes ða to heortan com, 132 ðæt ic ða ongan swa freolic man:
133 “Eala ðu milde ðe me ðus gefrefrode! 134 And ðu ðe ða hraðe ðinum hlaforde gehyrsumodest, 135 ða soðan word ðe he ðe sæde!
136 ðu hafast ðurh ðinne spræce ðone hyge min 137 ðurh ða wilnunga to ðam wege awend, 138 ðæt ic eom nu eft on ðam forman geþance.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Or va, ch’un sol volere è d’ambedue: 140 tu duca, tu segnore e tu maestro». 141 Così li dissi; e poi che mosso fue,
142 intrai per lo cammino alto e silvestro.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Now go, for a single will is in both of us: 140 you as leader, lord, and master." 141 Thus I said to him; and after he had moved,
142 I entered the high and wild path.
**Old English:**
139 Nu ga, for ðæt an willa is on us begen: 140 ðu heretoga, ðu hlaford and ðu lareow. 141 Ic ðus cwæð; and siððan he afaren wæs,
142 ic eode on ðone hean and wudufæstan weg.
